oysterFacts.fact: Humans have been cultivating and eating oysters for thousands of years.
Oysters change their gender once or more during their lifetime.
Oysters are rich in vitamins (B1, B3, B12, & D) and nutrients (copper, selenium, magnesium, phosophorous, & zinc.
Similar to wine, oysters have a variety of flavor profiles.
A single oyster can filter 30-50 gallons of water a day.
Legend holds that the Goddess of Love, Aphrodite, emerged from the sea in an oyster shell.
Pearls are a defensive mechanism from oyster irritants. It is the only gemstone to come from a living creature.
Oyster farms help improve the health of nearby waterways.
Oysters are only safe to eat raw only while they're alive.
A group of oysters is commonly called a colony, a bed or oyster reef.
The largest oyster is a Pacific oyster (Crassostrea gigas) and measures approximately 14 inches in length and 4 inches in width!

The word “oyster” comes from Old French oistre, and first appeared in English during the 14th century. The French derived from the Latin ostrea, the feminine form of ostreum, which is the latinisation of the Greek ὄστρεον (ostreon), “oyster”.
From the early 19th century and onwards, oysters sold tremendously from street vendors across New York, London, and Paris as they were a cheap and accessible snack for the working class.
Oysters are found in the Paleozoic era (542-251 millions years ago)!
Sergius Orata, a Roman hydraulic engineer, is credited as the inventor of oyster farming.
An oyster breathes like a fish, using both the gills and the mantle.
Oysters can live up to 20 years in captivity.
More than 85% of the world's oyster reefs have been lost.
In many cultures, oysters are seen as an aphrodisiac.
When oysters band together in colonies, they form a natural barrier against storm waves and sea level rises.
Oysters come in countless varieties, but there are only five species found in North American waters.
In New York City, Manhattan's oldest street, Pearl Street, is named so because it was covered with crushed oyster shells.
It's the location that gives the oyster its flavor, not its species.
The oyster that produces the commerical pearl is from a different oyster family than the edible oyster.
The Guinness World Record for the most oysters eaten in 3 minutes is 233 set by Colin Shirlow from Hillsborough, UK on September 3, 2005!
